ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: LING 219 was one of my favorite classes I took this year. The readings were interesting and connected really well to the methods we learned, and the final project was a lot of fun to work on since we treated it like an independent research project in the field. As a non-major, I felt a little disadvantaged in the discussions, but overall I was still able to get a lot out of the class. I would definitely recommend it to majors and non-majors alike.

This was a great course, and I learned a lot. Very manageable workload, and it's exciting because you actually get to apply what you learned for the final project. The professor is very knowledgeable and helpful, and the case studies we read were interesting.

This class was fairly interesting if you are very, very interested in the material. However, as someone who was only vaguely interested in the material, the class was a little too complicated and not engaging. The use of complex phylogenetic analysis softwares was overwhelming and poorly explained.

I would definitely tell a fellow student to approach this course with caution. For someone who is particularly interested in computational historical linguistics and has a strong background in statistical software, I would recommend the course, but otherwise I probably would not.
